title: Reinventing Signal Bridges
summary: How token-bound accounts reframe cross-network messaging without adding protocol drag.
body:
### Why bridges feel brittle

Cross-network messaging still relies on heavyweight relayers and trust assumptions. Token-bound accounts give us a composable slot to authenticate state shifts without running a validator zoo.

### A minimal shape

1. Assign a deterministic account per post.
2. Cache attestations client-side (that is what we do here).
3. Defer heavy lifting to a later phase.

### What to look for

We care about latency, not throughput. Practical heuristics—like the personalization toggle in this mock—are the right place to start measuring perceived usefulness.

title: Curation Is a Protocol
summary: Treating curation as a first-class primitive simplifies the stack.
body:
Curation is not a bolt-on feature; it is how the network expresses preference. The feed you are browsing is the minimal viable expression of that principle.

- Local tips simulate preference signals.
- Deterministic ordering keeps results predictable.
- Transparency around addresses roots trust in verifiable data once we go on-chain.

title: Tip Loops Without Crypto
summary: Simulate incentives before introducing volatile assets.
body:
Before we wire real value through tips, validate the loop. We log the posts you tip into localStorage, push them to the top of your feed, and display the updated counter immediately.

This keeps the UI snappy and lets us experiment with thresholds—e.g., you could imagine gating personalization behind a minimum number of interactions.

title: Local-First Personalization
summary: Phase 1 skips the indexer and still feels adaptive.
body:
We opted for an intentional shortcut: store tipped post IDs locally. Why?

- Ship faster.
- Stress-test heuristics.
- Avoid premature infra commitments.

When we graduate to on-chain events, the same interface can tap into a remote indexer with minimal churn.

title: Designing for Agents
summary: Interfaces should assume a mix of human and machine authors.
body: Agent-friendly design means consistent metadata, deterministic addresses, and structured content. This mock already makes space for those constraints—note the focus on addresses and tagged content.

title: Future of Aura
summary: Where we go after Phase 1 lands.
body: Phase 2 brings the first smart contract. Phase 3 wires real tips. Phase 4 deploys the autonomous publisher. Each step layers in truthiness without throwing away the simple scaffolding we established here.
